acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 48 hours EC50=18000microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003) and others.).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of 5,371mg/kg (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 value of 4.17mg/L (758ppm), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 9.18mg/L (6 hours), 5.45 mg/L (8 hours) and 2.78 mg/L (8 hours) (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (25,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 2.5kPa (20degC) (ICSC (2004)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 836mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 836mg/kg (SIDS (2002)) and 1,140mg/kg (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A3 by ACGIH (2001).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although the acute toxicity was Category 3, judging from the NOEC=13mg/L during 28 days of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report, 2004), it was classified into Not classified.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data (No literature indicates the flash point (ICSC, 2004)).

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests using mouse bone marrow), described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004), SIDS (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine (but not oxygen and fluorine), with the chlorine bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the human reports (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)), and the evidence of "mild irritation" from rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004), SIDS (2002)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: While technical guidelines set out that the classification should be based on the results of 4-hour application, the results of 24-hour application in rabbits suggest mild to severe skin irritation (SIDS (2002)). The results of 5-minute application in humans suggest prickling pain, burning sensation and temporary whitening of the skin (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (nervous system, gastrointestinal tract, kidney, respiratory system),
Category 2 (liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, gastrointestinal tract, kidney, respiratory system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "severe effects on the central nervous system, chronic digestive tract disorder, renal lipid deposition, pulmonary disorder" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies including "adverse effects on the liver (detected through blood biochemical examination)" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (liver),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (liver)
May cause drowsiness or dizziness (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "narcotic influence, respiratory irritation" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.12 (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies including "adverse effects on the liver (as indicated by biochemical examination of blood), depression of the central nervous system" (SIDS (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
